You are already home!
Question goes here

Go in nature by yourself with no predetermined route (or very minimal one) or length of time. What was the most exciting thing that happened during that walk? Were you thinking a lot? Or not at all? What was in your head?
Pick an artistic medium you are not comfortable with and just create. Try not to judge or compare yourself to others!
Reflection
With Others...
With Nature...
Hug A Tree!

"Find the most inspiring tree around your area, and give it a big hug.
While you’re there take a long breath, and thank that tree for the air you are breathing."
Was it your first experience of hugging a tree? How did you feel?
How do you feel about doing this exercise in public?
How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Walk Solo in Nature
Go in nature by yourself with no predetermined route (or very minimal one) or length of time.
What was the most exciting thing that happened during that walk?
Were you thinking a lot or not at all? What was in your head?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
Nature as a Child
Try to remember a memory from your childhood that you felt particularly connected with nature. Where was it? Who were with you? What were you doing?
What was the importance of nature during your childhood?
How did this memory or that particular place shape the relationship that you now have with nature?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
Do the Earth a Favor!
Walk around your local park or neighborhood and pick up a single piece of trash (or more!) off the ground. Make sure it finds its way to the proper bin! (Remember to compost or recycle if you can.)
Did you notice a lot (or very little) trash where you were walking? What was your initial reaction to the presence of or lack of trash in your immediate surroundings?
How did you feel carrying around someone else’s trash? When it made it to the bin, what was the first feeling that you had?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
The Elements

Connect mindfully with the four elements using all your senses. The four elements are Earth, Water, Fire and Air. For example, silence your thoughts, and stare at a lit candle, feel the soil with your bare feet, listen to the wind, and smell the ocean.
Which element did you feel the most connected to? Why?
Which sense did you naturally use the most to connect with each element?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
Adopt a Pet Plant!

Find a small plant that is seeding in a park, or in the woods. Gently up root it, and grab some of the soil that it was growing in. Bring it home, put it into a cup or jar, try to identify the species and its basic needs, and see what happens! You now have a new friend!
Why did you choose this plant? What attracted you to that particular plant?
Do you feel any emotional connection with the plant now that it’s home? Did you give it a name?
"How did this exercise influence your connection to nature? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?"
Disconnect and Unplug
Try to spend just one day (safely!) without your phone. Bonus points if you are actually still in the city, and not in the woods somewhere.
What was your initial reaction? Did you feel stress? Freedom?
When you got back on the grid, what was it like to use your device again?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Hard Food for Midas
Think of your relationship with money. Focus on your feelings around it, and your initial emotional reaction to your current financial situation.
What is more important to you than money? What would you not give up for any price in the world?
What would you consider “enough”? How big would your bank account have to be that when you see it, you feel safe and free to take opportunities?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Represent Local

"Local and state governments often have a much bigger effect on your life than federal. Attend a local city council meeting, or watch a session of your state congress. Attempt to meet your city council or state government representative. Is there any important local issue you could talk with them about?"
What issues did they discuss? Was there anything about the process that stood out to you?
Did you like your representative? How could you work with them to address the issues you feel concerned about?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Kindness on the Street
Give a panhandler some change or food. Ask them their name, and wish them a good day.
What was their reaction? Did their demeanor change once you asked for their name?
How did you feel after the interaction was over? Was there a sense of doing some good?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
A Little Earth for Charity

Sign up to make a small monthly donation (about the cost of a lunch, whatever you can afford) to a charity that advocates for a cause that you support. Any cause will do! A monthly donation makes you a real member of these organizations.
Question placeholder
Question placeholder
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
Volunteer
"“What is the essence of life? To serve others and to do good.” -Aristotle""
A tried and true classic to feel good and meet great people! Find a cause and organization you care about, and volunteer for a day. Even if it’s just once, you certainly won’t forget the experience.
Where did you choose to volunteer? What was the work like?
Did you build good relationships? Did you feel connected with the other volunteers? Your community as a whole?
How did this exercise influence your connection with society? Are there any insights or strong feelings that you will remember from this exercise?
